newsitem.title: USA: US corp bond players plan vacations amid no supply.
newsitem.headline: US corp bond players plan vacations amid no supply.

text.p: With nothing on the horizon for upcoming debt issues, corporate bond players are mapping out vacations plans rather than new business, dealers said.
"We don't have any bond issues on the plate for today or next week. Even our preferreds (deals) have been pretty much cleaned up this week," said one high-grade syndicate source.
Dealers said that going into next week issuance is expected to be next to nil with skeleton crews on deck ahead of the U.S. Labor Day holiday on September 2.
Another factor hurting potential debt issuance is the backup in U.S. Treasury yields after this morning's U.S. durable goods report, dealers added.
"The selloff in the Treasury market isn't helping anybody either," said another syndicate source.

Earlier, the Labor Department reported a stronger-than-expected 1.6 percent rise in July durable goods which triggered a drop in U.S. Treasuries and sent yields, which move in the opposite direction, higher.
Currently, the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond stands at 98-6/32 off 21/32 to yield 6.89 percent compared with 6.84 percent at Thursday's close.
"The market is extremely quiet. It should stay that way straight through the (Labor Day) holiday and into the next batch of (U.S.) employment data," one dealer said.
The U.S. Labor Department will release its next batch of employment data on Friday, September 6.
Turning to upcoming yankeee issues, ANZ-Australian New Zealand Bank is still expected to tap the new issue market with a $300 to $450 million in 10-year debt via Merrill Lynch & Co, sources said.
In Thursday's business, the U.S. Agency for International Development for Israel priced $1.0 billion total in zero coupon and fixed-rate debt, via Merrill Lynch and Lehman Brothers, respectively.
